content.description: Climb the easy slightly, right-leaning crack system to the chains
content.location: Located right of the Green Tongue.  Start behind the large pine tree.

content.description: Mixed route that climbs more like a sport climb than a crack climb with the exception of the short, but powerful crux. Starts with some big moves on good holds to gain the crux crack system. Boulder through the shallow crack to gain some very good holds. From here, I went straight up along more jugs, only to meet up with the last few moves (and crux) of the 5.10 to the right. However, it looked possible to move right earlier and clip the last three bolts of the 5.10 as well.
content.protection: A couple of bolts and gear to chain anchors with lower-off biners. The anchors are shared with the routes directly left and right. Easy TR by leading the fully bolted route to the right.
content.location:
The center of the clean, bolted face just uphill of

Lost and Found.

​​​​

content.description: Starts with some easier dihedral movement to the right of the first bolt. After a couple bolts of dihedral step-ups, move out onto the face and figure out the interesting, technical face moves through the last three bolts to the chains.
content.protection: 6 bolts to chain anchors with lower-off biners. The anchors are shared with the two routes to the left.
content.location:
The right side of the clean, bolted face just uphill of

Lost and Found.

content.description: Climb the stellar corner to the anchors.  Which is easier said than done - this thing's stout!
content.location: Located directly across the gulley from the Green Tongue.

climbs.name: Here For Now
climbs.fa: FA: Laine Christman (rope solo) FFA: Dan Kennedy

content.description:
This is like a mini OOTD in that it is steep, roofy, and traversey, but lacks the solid rock quality.

Start at a thin crack and left facing corner below a roof.  Traverse the roof and continue up the corner to a rest at another roof.  Place a piece and step left past the roof.  Continue up through a hand crack system.  From here either 1) travers left to a wide hand crack with a wedged block sticking out about half way up, 2) continue up a finger crack to a horizontal and move left into 1, or 3) go right and up another thin crack.  All points will take you to the anchors.  There is no real cruxy section, fairly continuous at the grade.

Be careful not to kick rocks down on other parties below you as the approach and some sections might contain loose rock. I try to clean it up a bit more.
content.protection: standard rack of double to 3 inch
content.location: Located at the top of the gulley, above the Green Tongue.  Start in the broken corner on an airy ledge. The belay might want a piece to anchor in to.

content.description: This is another fingery area classic.  Patience and good footwork will see you through.  Start up a mungey, broken crack system.  After about 10 feet, move into a very thin crack that continues to the chains. The crux consists of tenuous moves on insecure locks and is found about half way up.
content.protection: Thin to #1 with an emphasis on small nuts and cams will do.
content.location: Located about half way up the gulley, about 20 feet left of a prominent large pine tree.  Look for the Kiss-like green tongue of vegetation that marks the start.
